pullRequest.title: #18494 : Refactors and improves the performance in the Drop Old Asset…
pullRequest.bodyText:
… Versions tool.
In the CMSMaintenanceFactory class:

Narrows the potential list of Inodes to delete down by selecting the oldest Inode out of the list of objects that are actually versionable in dotCMS. Also, used the MIN() function to get the oldest date, not the previous approach. This means faster execution as there are less records to traverse.
Improves the task progress logging so users can keep track of of it.
Usual code refactoring.

In the ESContentFactoryImpl class:

Code attempted to solve ALL data inconsistencies in the Inode table along the way. This was carried out every time and caused the connection socket to close as that is an extremely heavy operation.
Now, we get the actual list of Inodes that need to be deleted. If there's any, then delete them. If not, just move on.
If there are Inodes, do a batch delete instead of deleting them all.
For some reason, this method takes care of deleting orphaned physical assets in the "/assets/" folder. It was doing it every time it was called even if no Inode records were deleted. Performance was improved by only executing this task when files are deleted. NOTE: R&D might consider removing this specific part of the code.

Using data from customer, the tool went from getting a "socket closed" exception after 5 minutes, to cleaning up almost 60,000 records in around 4.5 minutes in a local environment.

commit.message:
#18494 : Refactors and improves the performance in the Drop Old Asset Versions tool.

In the `CMSMaintenanceFactory` class:
1. Narrows the potential list of Inodes to delete down by selecting the oldest Inode out of the list of objects that are actually versionable in dotCMS. Also, used the `MIN()` function to get the oldest date, not the previous approach. This means faster execution as there are less records to traverse.
2. Improves the task progress logging so users can keep track of of it.
3. Usual code refactoring.

In the `ESContentFactoryImpl` class:
1. Code attempted to solve ALL data inconsistencies in the Inode table along the way. This was carried out every time and caused the connection socket to close as that is an extremely heavy operation.
2. Now, we get the actual list of Inodes that need to be deleted. If there's any, then delete them. If not, just move on.
3. If there are Inodes, do a batch delete instead of deleting them all.
4. For some reason, this method takes care of deleting orphaned physical assets in the "/assets/" folder. It was doing it every time it was called even if no Inode records were deleted. Performance was improved by only executing this task when files are deleted. NOTE: R&D might consider removing this specific part of the code.

Using data from customer, the tool went from getting a "socket closed" exception after 5 minutes, to cleaning up almost 60,000 records in around 4.5 minutes in a local environment.

commit.message: #18494 : Adding code review changes from Freddy Rodriguez and Codacy.

nodes.bodyText:
Just by separating this into two queries and using UNION on them you will probably get a high performance gain:
Original query
EXPLAIN ANALYSE SELECT inode FROM contentlet WHERE identifier <> 'SYSTEM_HOST' AND mod_date < now() AND NOT EXISTS
(SELECT working_inode, live_inode FROM contentlet_version_info WHERE working_inode = contentlet.inode OR
                live_inode = contentlet.inode)

Proposed query - One query for live, one for working and INTERSECT. That way you don't have an OR.
EXPLAIN ANALYSE SELECT inode FROM contentlet WHERE identifier <> 'SYSTEM_HOST' AND mod_date < now() AND NOT EXISTS
    (SELECT working_inode FROM contentlet_version_info WHERE working_inode = contentlet.inode)
INTERSECT
        SELECT inode FROM contentlet WHERE identifier <> 'SYSTEM_HOST' AND mod_date < now() AND NOT EXISTS
    (SELECT live_inode FROM contentlet_version_info WHERE live_inode = contentlet.inode)```

You can use a temp table instead and do a DELETE JOIN instead of having to use an IN.
Basically insert results of the previous suggested query (INTERSECT) into a temp table, and join against that temp table for doing the two DELETEs
Issue found: Avoid catching generic exceptions such as NullPointerException, RuntimeException, Exception in try-catch block
Issue found: Avoid variables with short names like dc
Issue found: A method/constructor should not explicitly throw java.lang.Exception
